events.title: General Franklyn Prepares for Strategic River Assault with French Cavalry Support Amidst Reduced Tank Strength
events.description: "During the evening e 20th May, General Franklyn completed his reconnaissances for an attack on the following day to secure the line of the rivers Scarpe and Cojeul: his intention was to exploit success by moving on 22nd May to the Sens e and thence towards Bapaume and Cambrai. In these plans he had the full co-operation of General Prioux, Commander of the French Cavalry Corps, but the light mechanised divisions were much  reduced in strength and probably had no more than one quarter of their tanks fit for action.

events.title: Swift Administrative Adaptability Shines Following May 20th Base Changes
events.description: The change of bases made necessary after 20th May was a fine example of quick decision, flexible administration, and the power of the administrative staffs at home and in France to improvise at short notice.

events.title: Dunkirk Evacuation: General Hospitals Cut Off, Casualty Clearing Stations Adapt to Crisis
events.description: By 20th May all the General Hospitals had been cut off from the forward area and improvised arrangements had to be made for the evacuation of casualties. Some of the Casualty Clearing Stations had to be diverted from their normal function and used as Hospitals. Hospital ships continued to berth at Dunkirk

events.title: Early Morning Assault: Heavy Bombing Strikes Maleme Aerodrome on May 20th
events.description: 60. The main enemy attack began soon. after  dawn on 20th May, with a heavy bombing attack on Maleme aerodrome. Under cover of

events.title: Air Force Strengthens Ground Troops with New Close Support Group Ahead of Key Operations
events.description: 27. The Air Force had nullified the enemy air opposition after attacks on Dessie aerodrome on 6th April and on Gimma aerodrome on 1oth April, and as the aircraft were therefore available I arranged with Air Headquarters for the formation of a close support group in order to give the divisional Commanders additional air support for their operations. During the advance of the 1st S.A. Brigade towards Dessie 4 Hartbees and 4 Gladiator aircraft had been put under the operational command of the Brigade Commander and the value of their close support had been proved. Accordingly a Close Support Group consisting of two flights of Battle bombers, one flight of Gladiator fighters and two flights of Hartbees co-operation aircraft, was formed on 20th May and put under command of 11th (A) Division.

events.title: Swift Deployment: 24th Guards Brigade and Irish Guards Join Forces in Bodo Mission
events.description: On the same day I despatched the Headquarters of the 24th Guards Brigade (for the third time) and half the South Wales Borderers in destroyers to Bodo which they reached safely on 20th May. They were followed on 2ist May by two Companies of the Irish Guards in   puffers , the journey by   puffer   taking about 24 hours against nine by destroyers,

events.title: Strategic Meetings in Dover Coordinate Large-Scale Evacuation Plans Across the Channel
events.description: 3. Further meetings were held at Dover on the 20th May, and at the War Office on the 21st May, to consider the   emergency evacuation across the Channel of very large Forces.  These meetings determined the number of personnel vessels and small craft available, and confirmed that the control of all sea movements rested with the Vice Admiral, Dover, a liaison officer from the War Office Movement Control and from the Ministry of Shipping being attached to the Vice Admiral.

events.title: Commander's Key Communication: Strategic Insights from Cairo, May 1942
events.description: Letter from the Commander-in-Chief, M.E.F., to the Commander, Eighth Army. Cairo, 20th May, 1942.

events.title: Command Transition: 4 Corps Takes Charge as Burcorps Rear Guard Relinquished
events.description: At 1800 hours on the 20th May I placed the rear guard of x Burcorps under command of 4 Corps and my task came to an end.

events.title: General Alexander Reports on Critical Burma Operations: March-May 1942
events.description: Report by General the Honourable Sw Harold RIL. G. Alexander, K.C B., C SJ., DS O., MC, on Operations in Burma from 5ih March, 1942, to 20th May, 1942. .

events.title: Command Under Fire: Chronicles of Burma's Defense from December '41 to May '42
events.description: 1 This despatch covers reports by Lieut.- General T. J. Hutton and by General The Honourable Sir Harold R. L. G. Alexander describing the operations in Burma between 15th December, 1941, when the defence of Burma became the responsibility of the Commander-in-Chief in India, and 20th May,  1942, when the last troops of the Burma Army were withdtawn across the frontier into India. The despatch is intended to explain how the general strategical situation affected operations in Burma and to record the actions I took as the Commander chiefly responsible for them. Although the defence of Burma was three times transferred from one Command to another during the period, I remained personally responsible except for a period of about one week at the end of February, 1942.

events.title: Naval Task Force D Set to Navigate Anti Kithera Channel and Sweep Key Capes
events.description: (a) Force D consisting of R.A.D. in DIDO -with ORION, AJAX, ISIS, KIMBERLEY,  IMPERIAL and JANUS, was to pass the Anti Kithera Channel by 2200/20th May, sweep Capes Malea Hydra Phalconera and be off Canea at 0700/2ist.

events.title: Battle of Crete Ignites: Navy Strikes a Heavy Blow to German Forces
events.description: 4. The air attack on Crete started on the 20th May, 1941. The sweeps of the Light Forces on the night 2oth/2zst and during daylight 21st were uneventful except for heavy air attacks and the unlucky loss of H.M.S. JUNO (see paragraphs 14 to 20).  As far as the Navy was concerned, the real Battle of Crete began on the night of 21st/22nd May, with the successful encounter of Force D with an enemy convoy (see paragraph 23). This encounter was. skilfully and thoroughly exploited, was a heavy blow to the Germans and an encouragement for our hard pressed troops in Crete.

events.title: Chaos in the Harbour: 15 Ships Offload 15,000 Tons of Army Supplies Amidst Air Attacks
events.description: 3. During the period Bre 2gth April to 20th May, some 15,000 tons of Army stores were offloaded from 15 ships, whilst eight ships were sunk or damaged in the harbour by air attack.

events.title: Strategic Reserves: Alexandria on Alert as Naval Forces Brace for Impending Crete Assault
events.description: Alexandria, which is 420 miles from Suda, A force was to be held in reserve at Alexandria as an attack might-start at a time when our forces at sea were getting short of fuel. Although the first airborne attack on Crete did not take lace until the 20th May, naval forces had to be kept teaay  at sea from the 14th May onwards

events.title: May 20th: A Day of Anticipation and Unfolding Events
events.description: 20th May. . .

events.title: Canadians Forge Ahead: 3rd Infantry Brigade Advances Near Garigliano
events.description: North of Capua concentrated west of R, Garigliano 20th May passed through 3 Cdn. Inf. Bde. 24th May.

events.title: Home Fleet Prepares for Strategic Maneuvers: A Look Ahead to May 20, 1942
events.description: Home Fleet, , 20th May, 1942.

events.title: Record Convoy of 35 Ships Sets Sail Amidst Adverse Conditions, Faces Enemy Air Assault
events.description: 26. P.Q.16, which sailed on 20th May, contained 35 ships and, despite the fact that this was the most unfavourable time of the year, was the largest convoy which had so far been me It was escorted by five destroyers, four ites, four trawlers, one minesweeper and A.A. ship.
